docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''G.O.P. Senate Leaders Back Bill on Insuring Infertility Treatments'' (news article, Feb. 8): The New York State Senate has recognized the responsibility of insurance companies to cover infertility treatments, yet the senators block pending legislation to require insurers to cover birth control. Most women spend much of their lives trying to avoid unintended pregnancy, often paying hundreds of dollars each year.
docs.abstract: Sara Sills letter on Feb 8 article scores New York State Senate for opposing insurance coverage for birth control while backing bill to require insurers to pay for infertility treatments

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''France Provides MorningAfter Pill to Schoolgirls'' (front page, Feb. 8): France's efforts to dispense emergency contraception to teenage girls should be applauded. As a recent graduate of a public high school on Long Island, I was provided with little sex education and was not offered any form of contraception through my school's health office, an experience shared by many other young Americans.
docs.abstract: Serena Josel letter on Feb 8 article hails France's efforts to dispense emergency contraception to teenage girls

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Planned Parenthood Gets Limited Permit'' [Feb. 6] quotes Jerome Higgins as saying, ''Their whole thrust is to promote value-free sex education in the schools, which leads to promiscuity, which leads to pregnancy, which leads to abortion.'' As co-chairman of the education committee of Planned Parenthood of Nassau County, to which Mr. Higgins is referring, I suggest that if he would attend one of our education workshops or speak to any child or parent who has attended, he might be better informed.
docs.abstract: Community Presbyterian Church Pastor Thomas J Philipp letter disputes Jerome Higgins' Feb 6 letter contending that Planned Parenthood's sex education classes lead to promiscuity, pregnancy and abortion (S)

Bars Marketing of Supplements to Pregnant Women,'' news article, Feb. 10).

docs.lead_paragraph: In a prudent turnabout, the Food and Drug Administration has decided to suspend a regulation that it issued last month that would have allowed the manufacturers of dietary supplements to assert that their products ease the symptoms of pregnancy. Faced with sharp protests from public health experts, the agency has decided to hold public meetings to review this dangerous new rule as it applies to pregnancy-related claims. In the freewheeling supplement market, consumers get very little protection from government regulators on the safety or effectiveness of these products. When pregnancy is involved, this lack of regulation can pose serious hazards, since a product that may do no harm to the woman could potentially cause birth defects. At present, there is very little research on the kinds of plant compounds that might pose a risk for fetuses.

headline.main: A Wise Pause on Dietary Supplements

docs.abstract: Editorial says Food and Drug Administration was right to suspend its recently issued regulation that would have allowed manufacturers of dietary supplements to assert that their products ease symptoms of pregnancy; calls on FDA to permanently bar all supplement manufacturers from making claims related to pregnancy, and to do all it can to discourage pregnant women from comsuming untested products
docs.snippet: In a prudent turnabout, the Food and Drug Administration has decided to suspend a regulation that it issued last month that would have allowed the manufacturers of dietary supplements to assert that their products ease the symptoms of pregnancy....

docs.lead_paragraph: A woman whose doctor carved his initials into her skin after he delivered her baby by Caesarean section has settled a lawsuit against the doctor and dropped her claim against Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan, the hospital said yesterday. Under the terms of the settlement, the patient, Dr. Liana Gedz, a dentist, will receive $1.75 million, according to people who were involved in the settlement talks.

headline.main: Patient Settles Case Of Initials Cut in Skin

docs.abstract: Liana Gedz settles lawsuit against Dr Allan Zarkin, who carved his initials into her skin after delivering her baby by Caesarean section; she also drops claim against Beth Israel Medidcal Center in Manhattan; Gedz reportedly will get $1.75 million (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Brooklyn detectives have arrested a teacher's aide in a special education program and charged him with rape after discovering that a 13-year-old girl he had dated was eight-and-a-half-months pregnant. The girl had been a student last year at Intermediate School 14 in Sheepshead Bay, which is housed in the same building as the special education program, the police said yesterday. The girl, whose name was withheld because of the nature of the crime, told investigators she was dating the aide, Andre Gerard, 30, who works with handicapped students, the police said.

headline.main: Teacher's Aide Charged In Rape of Girl, 13

docs.lead_paragraph: A Manhattan obstetrician pleaded not guilty to felony assault charges yesterday for carving his initials into a woman's belly after performing a Caesarean section last fall. The arraignment of the doctor, Allan Zarkin, was his first public appearance since the incident at Beth Israel Medical Center was reported. He was animated in the courtroom, chatting with his lawyers and a former patient, but he declined to speak with reporters after his appearance in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

headline.main: Obstetrician Pleads Not Guilty in Carving

docs.abstract: Dr Allan Zarkin pleads not guilty to felony assault charges for carving his initials into a woman's belly after performing Caesarean section last fall at Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan; patient, Dr Liana Gedz, is suing Zarkin, his former practice and Beth Israel for $5.5 million; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-20 Kurds Respond to Call To End War Against Turkey Kurdish rebels who have been fighting for self-rule in Turkey since 1984 said they would press their cause peacefully and democratically. Since their leader, Abdullah Ocalan, was captured a year ago, he has urged his fighters to lay down their arms. A14 Hijackers Free Some Captives Dozens of the 150 or so people held aboard a hijacked Afghan airliner at a British airport were allowed to leave, officials said. On Tuesday night, four flight crew members escaped through a window. A15

docs.lead_paragraph: Under pressure from experts in birth defects, the Food and Drug Administration today withdrew, at least for now, a new rule that allowed dietary supplements to be sold for common pregnancy-related conditions like morning sickness and leg swelling. Unlike drugs, supplements do not require rigorous testing for safety and efficacy, and the new F.D.A. rule, which took effect on Monday, drew fire from birth defects experts, who said it would put unborn babies at risk.

headline.main: F.D.A. Bars Marketing of Supplements to Pregnant Women
